metadata.case_name: Amalgamated Coalfields Ltd. & Ors. v. Janapada Sabha, Chhindwara
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 469, 470, 506, 507 and 529 to 534 of 1962; Petitions Nos. 70 and 71 of 1962

facts.text: Appellants are colliery companies holding mining leases under Government of Madhya Pradesh for extraction of coal from collieries in Chhindwara District.
Respondent Janapada Sabha, Chhindwara is successor of Independent Mining Local Board which had status and powers of District Council under Central Provinces Local Self Government Act, 1920.
On March 12, 1935, Mining Board resolved under s.51 of 1920 Act to levy coal tax; sanctioned by local Government on December 16, 1935 via Notification No. 8700-2253-D-VIII, effective January 1, 1936.

On December 16, 1935, local Government notified rules under s.79(1)(xv) and (xxx); Rule 2: tax payable by mining lease holders; Rule 3: 3 pies per ton on coal, coal dust or coke manufactured at mines, sold for export by rail or otherwise within Board's jurisdiction.
In 1943, words 'coke manufactured at the mines' deleted from Rule 3; tax confined to coal and coal dust.
Rate increases: December 22, 1943 to 4 pies/ton; July 29, 1946 to 7 pies/ton; July 19, 1947 to 9 pies/ton.
1920 Act repealed in 1948; replaced by Central Provinces and Berar Local Self-Government Act, 1948 (No. 38 of 1948); Sabha continued levy.

Appellants in CAs 469/470: Amalgamated Coalfields Ltd. and Pench Valley Coal Co. Ltd.; notices August 23, 1958 demanding Rs.21,898/64 np and Rs.11,838/9 np at 9 pies/ton for Jan-Jun 1958, including coal despatched outside MP.
Writ Petition No.31/1959 in SC challenging 1958 notices; dismissed February 10, 1961 (Amalgamated Coalfields Ltd. v. Janapada Sabha, 1962 1 SCR 1).
Further notices: September 13, 1960 (Rs.1,16,776/25 np) and March 2, 1961 (Rs.65,261/19 np) at 9 pies/ton for half-years ending Jun30/Dec31 1958-1960.
Writ in MP HC No.95/1961 (Apr12,1961) and No.213/1961 challenging notices Jun9,1959 demanding Rs.1,92,144/66 np and Rs.68,319/36 np for Apr1,1951-Dec31,1957 on exported coal.
MP HC dismissed petitions Dec18,1961 holding barred by res judicata; special leave granted Apr23,1962 leading to CAs 469/470/1962.
Writ Petitions 70/71/1962 in SC under Art.32 challenging Jun9,1959 and Sep13,1960 notices.
CA 506/1962: Central Provinces Syndicate Ltd. challenged notice for Rs.20,776/88 np arrears Apr1,1951-Jun30,1959 including outside state coal; reopening assessment.
CA 507/1962: Kanhaan Valley Coal Co. Pvt. Ltd. challenged notice Rs.10,970/- arrears Apr1,1951-Jun30,1959.
CAs 529-534/1962: Newton Chickli Collieries Pvt. Ltd. & 5 others challenged notices for arrears on exported coal.

Post-Constitution, Sabha stopped collecting tax on coal exported outside MP from ~1952 on advice; resumed after MP HC decision Aug6,1958 in Newton Chickli writ No.265/1957 holding not sales tax/excise.
Rule 3 deleted by notification Sep6,1943 published Sep10,1943.
Rules 3-10: Assessment based on lessee/railway figures; half-yearly statements; Chairman assesses; notice; 15 days objections; finality under Rule 10.
Roads constructed by Board at mining interests' request; tax origin to recover benefit.

legal_issues.text: Whether doctrine of res judicata applies to writ petitions under Art.32/226, particularly constructive res judicata for different tax periods and distinct grounds.
Whether coal tax levy and rules violate Art.19(1)(f).
Whether rate increase from 3 to 9 pies/ton valid without previous sanction under s.51(2) of 1920 Act; construction of 'first imposition'.
Whether assessments can be reopened for past periods to include tax on exported coal; finality under Rule 10.
Whether tax is excise duty or sales tax limiting increases under Art.143 GOIA 1935/Art.277 Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Res judicata does not apply to Art.32/226 writs for different periods/grounds; earlier SC decision (1962 1 SCR 1) did not decide rate increase point on merits.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Pandit M.S.M. Sharma; Daryao v. State of UP; English cases like Gaffoor v. Income-tax Commissioner

petitioner_arguments.text: Levy violates Art.19(1)(f) as arbitrary/unreasonable like in Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.19(1)(f); Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala (1961 3 SCR 77)

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule 3 prescribes maximum 3 pies/ton under s.79(1)(xv); increases invalid.
Rate increases are 'first imposition' requiring previous sanction under s.51(2); no sanction obtained; notifications by Board only.
Reopening past assessments barred by finality in Rule 10; no provision like IT Act s.34/35.
Tax is excise/sales tax; increases beyond 3 pies invalid under Art.143 GOIA 1935/Art.277.

respondent_arguments.text: Challenges barred by res judicata per earlier SC decision.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Amalgamated Coalfields Ltd. v. Janapada Sabha (1962 1 SCR 1)

respondent_arguments.text: 'First imposition' in s.51(2) means only initial levy, not rate increases.
Rate increases sanctioned; tax not excise/sales tax.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Krishna Ram Nath v. Janapad Sabha (1962 Supp 3 SCR 70)

court_reasoning.text: General res judicata applies to Art.32/226 writs, but not constructive res judicata for different periods/grounds; earlier decision did not decide rate increase.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decision for one year does not bar subsequent years; follows English trend (Gaffoor, Society of Medical Officers).

court_reasoning.text: Tax levy/rules not violative of Art.19(1)(f); provides objection opportunity, quasi-judicial; unlike Moopil Nair.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of ss.51,79 and Rules 3-10 fair.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 3 deleted 1943; no max rate issue.
'First imposition' s.51(2) includes rate increases needing sanction; no sanction shown for 4/7/9 pies; notifications by Board only.
Rule 10 finality bars reopening past assessments; no other reopening provision.
No need to decide excise/sales tax nature given other grounds.

holdings.text: Res judicata (constructive) does not bar writs under Art.32/226 for different tax periods/grounds.
Coal tax levy valid at 3 pies/ton; increases to 9 pies invalid without s.51(2) sanction.
Reopening completed assessments barred by Rule 10.

precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier decision upholding initial notices; res judicata discussed but not barring new grounds.

precedents_cited.relevance: Principle of res judicata beyond jurisdiction/subject matter.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala
Society of Medical Officers of Health v. Hope
precedents_cited.relevance: No res judicata in tax/rating for subsequent periods.

precedents_cited.case_name: Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. v. Municipal Council
precedents_cited.relevance: No res judicata for different tax year valuation.
No res judicata in tax for subsequent years.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Local Self Government Act, 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to impose tax; rules for assessment/collection/max rates; 'first imposition' needs sanction.

Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writs for fundamental rights; res judicata; binding precedents; trade restriction; inter-state trade.

outcome.summary: Appeals and writ petitions allowed; notices invalid for tax at rates higher than 3 pies per ton (no s.51(2) sanction) and for reopening past assessments (Rule 10 finality); restrained from recovering beyond 3 pies/ton or additional on assessed years.
outcome.relief_granted: Quash notices demanding >3 pies/ton and additional tax on past periods; permanent restraint on such recovery.

key_quotes.text: "the decision for the levy of a tax for one year does not operate as res judicata in dealing with the question of a tax for the subsequent year."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on res judicata in tax matters for different periods.

key_quotes.text: "if the rates are increased and levy is sought to be imposed on the altered rates, the imposition of the levy at these altered rates should be deemed to be included in the expression 'first imposition' under s.51(2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Construction of s.51(2) requiring sanction for rate hikes.

key_quotes.text: "the scheme clearly provides that at the end of each six monthly period, the tax has to be assessed... and under Rule 10, the two decisions specified therein become final."
key_quotes.speaker: court
